0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: A recent study compared siblings conceived before and after nearby oil spills and find that nearby oil spills double the neonatal mortality rate.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: Not only that found that pollution is placing communities at heightened risk of kidney damage, as well as diseases such as cancer, diabetes, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s.

3.speaker: The Doctor
3.text: If we keep up the oil production, more and more communities are going to have to face this danger.

image.attribution: Greenpeace Russia, CC BY 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Farmer
0.text: We haven't been able to maintain a decent chocolate harvest for some time now...

1.speaker: The Farmer
1.text: The world's gotten used to plentiful coffee and chocolate!

2.speaker: The Farmer
2.text: ...but we may be slinking back to the time when they were inaccessible luxuries!

3.speaker: The Farmer
3.text: ...coffee's not any better. Fewer and fewer places have the right growing conditions.

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: I worry that pollinator populations are declining to dangerously low levels.

1.speaker: The Farmer
1.text: Crop yields have been a bit lower than expected...this might be why.

2.speaker: The Farmer
2.text: Bees may be small, but they are a crucial part of modern farming!

4.speaker: The Farmer
4.text: Without them we wouldn't be able to produce nearly as many crops.

5.speaker: The Ecologist
5.text: A collapse in pollinators will affect more than just crop yields.

6.speaker: The Ecologist
6.text: We need to improve biodiversity and lower extinction pressures to avoid catastrophe.

8.speaker: The Economist
8.text: Worldwide, honeybees yield roughly $200 billion in pollination services!

9.speaker: The Ecologist
9.text: The use of pesticides and fungicides is suspected to be a contributor to colony collapse disorder.

0.speaker: The Soldier
0.text: Regional borders are under attack now from people desperate to find refuge outside of their home regions.

1.speaker: The Soldier
1.text: ...but they are escalating their tactics.

3.speaker: The Soldier
3.text: We're doing our best to maintain the border and prevent crossings...

4.speaker: Gossy
4.text: And popular opinion is rapidly turning against you...

5.speaker: Gossy
5.text: ...maybe it's time to reconsider these hard borders?

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: Wildfires are growing in intensity and frequency.

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: Many of the people effected are elderly and are not tech savy so they don't trust "apps". They think they are talking to a robot.

next.text: Team up with a mental health startup to provide teletherapy.

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: People are suffering form PTSD from losing their homes, possessions, and pets. This is a mental health crisis!

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: So many others have had similar experiences.

4.speaker: The Climatologist
4.text: They've ravaged countless communities across the globe.

5.speaker: The Citizen
5.text: A home I spent years building and making my own was gone in an instant...

6.speaker: The Citizen
6.text: How can anyone live like this?

0.speaker: The Utopian
0.text: Finally, we can put that awful stuff behind us.

2.speaker: The Utopian
2.text: Not as soon as we'd needed to, but hopefully not too late either.

3.speaker: The Utopian
3.text: What a weight lifted of our shoulders though, eh?

image.attribution: "06022012 Double rainbow panorama" by StormRider93 | Into the Storm CC BY-NC-SA 2.0

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: I was helping out with a local remediation project, and we were clearing out some invasive plants that were upsetting the local ecosystem.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: Turns out you can ferment them into a pretty nice refreshment!

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: Now I'm seeing everyone volunteer at remediation sites to see what they can brew up!

image.attribution: Topi Pigula, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: I've got a small restaurant because I love cooking for others.

next.text: Wait a minute, jellyfish isn't vegan...

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: Seems like it's becoming quite the food trend!

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: I sent some to a few other chefs and we ended up putting together a book of jellyfish recipes.

5.speaker: The Citizen
5.text: The other day a neighbor brought in a ton of jellyfish...I guess they're everywhere now.

image.attribution: Eric Kilby from Somerville, MA, USA, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Consumerist
0.text: Hey!

1.speaker: The Consumerist
1.text: They're extremists!

2.speaker: The Consumerist
2.text: Look, you look like someone who's more...reasonable than these other parties.

3.speaker: The Consumerist
3.text: Otherwise I fear what they're going to take next.

4.speaker: The Consumerist
4.text: My party is joining your coalition, so we can keep them in check together.

5.speaker: The Consumerist
5.text: I'm a socialist, but these people are extreme!

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: There's so much room in the city now that cars are gone!

1.speaker: The Farmer
1.text: This is great news! This'll take some load off of other parts of the food system.

2.speaker: The Farmer
2.text: And opens up a bit more free time for me!

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: Urban gardening was something my neighborhood enjoyed doing...

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: ...but with all this extra space we began reclaiming plots for larger scale urban farming.

5.speaker: The Citizen
5.text: So far things are going well--we've been able to meet quite a bit of our own food needs.

6.speaker: The Farmer
6.text: These communities will be more resilient to food supply problems, so that's one less thing to worry about.

0.speaker: The Consumerist
0.text: You are *killing* me with these plans!

1.speaker: The Consumerist
1.text: I almost miss the days before the revolution.

2.speaker: The Consumerist
2.text: My life has only gotten worse.

3.speaker: The Consumerist
3.text: I won't let you drag me down with you!

4.speaker: The Consumerist
4.text: I wanted change, but this is ridiculous.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: All national borders were dissolved soon after the revolution.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: Of course, regional inequities haven't vanished overnight, so regions are still distinct from one another.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: Here you can gain some insight on those differences and learn more about each region.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: Now the world is organized into regions.

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: Flooding is getting even worse than before.

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: Even if people can move back into their homes, they'll suffer severe health consequences for it!

3.speaker: The Climatologist
3.text: These floods are effecting millions of people and it's becoming impossible to live in some places.

4.speaker: The Doctor
4.text: Mold and mildew grows within 24 hours after flooding since it's drain water that floods homes...

5.speaker: The Economist
5.text: We'll have to raise taxes.

next.text: Regulate the price on flood insurance.

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: We've identified several leaking nuclear storage tanks, many of which long ago outlived their design lives.

2.speaker: The Engineer
2.text: It should be resolved soon, but I'm sure it will shake people's confidence.

3.speaker: The Engineer
3.text: We're dealing with it now, but the leaks have contaminated the subsurface and are threatening the nearby river.

15.name: Collapse of the Greenland Ice Sheet

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: This is bad. A collapse this large and the displacement of that much water will surely have other effects.

0.speaker: The Geoengineer
0.text: Did you know there is evidence that the Sinai once was green – as recently as 4,500 to 8,000 years ago. Cave paintings found there depict trees and plants!

0.speaker: The Farmer
0.text: Higher temperatures have altered soil microbial ecology, causing additional carbon to be released.

1.speaker: The Farmer
1.text: That'll just make things hotter...you can see where this is going.

image.attribution: Kurt Kaiser, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Farmer
0.text: Crop yields are taking a hit because of that grey shroud we have around our planet.

1.speaker: The Farmer
1.text: The solar radiation management initiative is upsetting my plants! They like sun, ya know.

0.speaker: The Geoengineer
0.text: Our inspiration for the second moon is a French artist, who imagined a necklace of mirrors circling the Earth to illuminate the nighttime streets of Paris with reflected sunshine.

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: Water just isn't doing what it used to. Some places are seeing torrential rainfall become commonplace...

2.speaker: The Climatologist
2.text: I'm sure you can guess what you need to do...

4.speaker: The Climatologist
4.text: ...but bring down the temperature anomaly and I bet we'll see this get better.

5.speaker: The Climatologist
5.text: ...so flooding is becoming more frequent and more severe.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Big news--a proof for P = NP has been discovered.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: At the least we'll be able to speed up our research across the board!

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: I'll spare you the details, but suffice to say this will help greatly in all sorts of applications.

image.attribution: Rama & Musée Bolo, CC BY-SA 2.0 FR, via Wikimedia Commons

24.name: Are We Protecting Too Much Land in Nature Preserves?

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is taking a lot of land out of use. We'll have much less land for food...are you sure this is a good idea?

25.name: A Global Dustbowl: Unsustainable Loss of Top Soil

0.speaker: The Farmer
0.text: I heard there were storms like this is my great grandfather's time.

1.speaker: The Farmer
1.text: As I see it, we have two options. Either expand our agricultural lands at the expense of wilderness or try other kinds of farming.

2.speaker: The Farmer
2.text: Yields have peaked and they'll decline.

3.speaker: The Farmer
3.text: The soil just is blown away because we've ruined the land.

4.speaker: The Farmer
4.text: Industrial agriculture gives us high yields, but it's like mining the soil.

5.speaker: The Farmer
5.text: Pesticides, fertilizer, and irrigation each take their toll.

7.speaker: The Farmer
7.text: About nearly half of global farmland is degraded and we're still losing 24b tonnes of top soil every year.

image.attribution: Jorge Barrios, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: First the Great Barrier Reef, and now the very last coral has bleached.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: I don't know if we can bring them back...

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: ...but at the very least we can prevent something like this from happening again.

image.attribution: Caitlin Seaview Survey, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: Holy Moly, we're running out of petroleum. It will be gone in twenty years, I reckon.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: They're controversial, but will ensure we have plenty oil for our energy needs.

2.speaker: The Engineer
2.text: Or...you could open up non-conventional oil sources.

3.speaker: The Engineer
3.text: Either cut down your energy-use or find another source of energy fast.

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: I'm getting reports of a novel mosquito-borne disease spreading quickly.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: They've always been troublesome parasites--malaria kills hundreds of thousands of people per year--but in many parts of the world they weren't considered more than a nuisance.

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: Now they're much more dangerous.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: Warmer temperatures have been a boon for mosquito populations, so it was only a matter of time before this happened.

0.speaker: The Spacer
0.text: Reports of strange lights in the skies are coming in from all over the world.

1.speaker: The Spacer
1.text: What could it mean?

31.name: Most of World Self-Sufficient in Plant Crops

0.speaker: The Farmer
0.text: We've hit a nice milestone today!

2.speaker: The Farmer
2.text: Of course, regions still trade food here and there for varieties that can't grow at home.

3.speaker: The Farmer
3.text: But now people have a more direct connection to the food they eat than they ever have.

4.speaker: The Farmer
4.text: Most of the world is self-sufficient in crop production. I never thought I'd see the day.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: {region} has seceded from Gosplant.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: This is a major blow to Gosplant...

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: ...but maybe we'll survive it.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: They felt neglected by your decision-making and lost all confidence in your capacity as planner.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: The area around the Niger Delta was brought to the edge of total destruction from unrestrained oil production.

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: But thankfully, our remediation and restoration efforts have brought it back from the brink.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: I never expected to see the area so revitalized, although I had always hoped I would.

image.attribution: Terry Whalebone from Bolton, UK, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: Heatwaves are becoming even more frequent and intense.

1.speaker: The Climatologist
1.text: It's absolutely unbearable in some regions. We really can only reasonably live within a fairly limited range of temperatures.

2.speaker: The Climatologist
2.text: We need to get things under control...I fear what may happen if we don't.

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: This is a disaster. A major nuclear power plant went critical last night.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: I'm sure this will undermine people's confidence in nuclear power.

2.speaker: The Engineer
2.text: We're doing our best to contain it but quite a lot of damage has already been done.

3.speaker: The Engineer
3.text: But we'll work quickly and do what we can.

0.speaker: The Accelerationist
0.text: ...you've been doing great as planner...

1.speaker: The Accelerationist
1.text: ...i feel like we're on the same wavelength...

2.speaker: The Accelerationist
2.text: ...together we can manifest a world of incredible material abundance and luxury for everyone...

3.speaker: The Accelerationist
3.text: ..my party will join your coalition...

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Well, this is some exciting news.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: (I'm sure I could have solved it, if I weren't so busy here...)

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: The long elusive general solution to the infamous Navier-Stokes equation has been discovered.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: This will no doubt have a substantial impact all fields of research and engineering.

image.attribution: Kterletska, CC BY 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Umm... planner?

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: That local people are furious with our plans - for privileging the wealthy countries of this world.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: Harassment of Gosplant envoys, and vandalising infrastructure is becoming commonplace.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: Our offices in South America, Asia and Africa have all started to notice the same thing:

4.speaker: Gossy
4.text: What can we do?

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: The riots have now escalated into full-blown revolt in some regions.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: You need to take action that will assuage their fears and help their outlook.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: The people are extremely upset with how things have gone the last several years.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: Otherwise this will end badly.

0.speaker: The Spacer
0.text: We have all the technologies in place to send out ships to settle new planets.

1.speaker: The Spacer
1.text: We can't save Earth, at least not for everyone.

2.speaker: The Spacer
2.text: I urge you to focus establishing extraterrestrial human colonies...

3.speaker: The Spacer
3.text: ...so that at least some of our species will survive.

0.speaker: The Leather Underground
0.text: Planner! How can you force these kinds of dietary restrictions on us?

1.speaker: The Leather Underground
1.text: You ought to...reconsider...that policy.

2.speaker: The Leather Underground
2.text: Humans are *omnivores*--we need to eat meat!

3.speaker: The Leather Underground
3.text: And none of those silly substitutes can ever replicate the real thing.

0.speaker: The Posadist
0.text: Our dolphin friends have so much to teach us.

1.speaker: The Posadist
1.text: For example, their method of water-birthing unlocks the secret of how humans can be birthed in space.

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: This is obvious now, but it's getting quite a bit warmer.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: The "nightshift" has been said to increase health risks as well as potentially shorten lifespan!

2.speaker: The Engineer
2.text: As we rely more heavily on air conditioners and fans, electricity usage will get higher.

3.speaker: The Climatologist
3.text: Heatwaves are getting more frequent and intense.

6.speaker: The Engineer
6.text: Just something to be aware of.

7.speaker: Gossy
7.text: Energy companies have been preemptively shutting down power to avoid the possibility of sparking fires in the dry, windy conditions.  Pre-emptive blackouts could become a common occurrence.

8.speaker: The Engineer
8.text: The increased demand for electricity, especially during peak periods, over-taxes the electrical grid, triggering brownouts and blackouts

9.speaker: The Doctor
9.text: We are seeing an overload of hospitalizations for people with outdoor professions...

10.speaker: The Doctor
10.text: construction workers, miners, firefighters, agricultural workers, and the like.

next.text: Change the work hours of the day for outdoor workers.

image.attribution: Anderson Mancini from Sao Paulo, Brazil, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: [GAME]
0.text: Your legacy as a planner was one that you feared most:

1.speaker: [GAME]
1.text: If only you could go back and try again...

2.speaker: [GAME]
2.text: ...leaving the world in a worse shape than you found it.

0.speaker: The Farmer
0.text: It's either too little or too much water! Seems we can't get a good middle ground.

1.speaker: The Farmer
1.text: More droughts and floods, more crop failures...we can't seem to catch a break!

0.speaker: The Animal Liberationist
0.text: You're an unrepentant murderer!

1.speaker: The Animal Liberationist
1.text: You throw away non-human life like it's nothing.

2.speaker: The Animal Liberationist
2.text: I will do whatever I can to stop you and defend the animal life you value so little.

0.speaker: The Geoengineer
0.text: You know Edvard Munch's painting 'The Scream'? Well, its surreal sunset was caused by the eruption of Krakatau in 1883.

1.speaker: The Geoengineer
1.text: So, we'll have white skies during the day and blood red sunsets. Some might like it but most will probably find the new sky disturbing.

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: More and more people are overwhelmed by dread. They fear a future of climatic disasters and mass extinction.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: This is causing serious mental health disorders, especially in the younger generations.

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: You have to cool the planet and stop the Sixth Extinction so people can have hope.

image.attribution: no, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: The overuse of anti-biotics in animal husbandry has caused this problem.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: We estimate ten million people will die a year from what used to be preventable infections.

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: It takes years of research to make new antibiotics, but now resistant strains emerge within a year.

image.attribution: NIH Image Gallery from Bethesda, Maryland, USA, Public domain

0.speaker: The Ecofeminist
0.text: I see that patriarchy didn't die with the revolution, but rather transformed.

1.speaker: The Ecofeminist
1.text: The same dynamics and attitudes that got us into these crises have found a way to persist in you and your disastrous plans.

2.speaker: The Ecofeminist
2.text: It's time we stamp them out for good.

0.speaker: The Farmer
0.text: These monoculture crop systems...

1.speaker: The Farmer
1.text: we ought to consider a move away from industrial agriculture.

2.speaker: The Farmer
2.text: It saves me some effort, but it's just not worth betting our food supply on it.

image.attribution: "AKK 8-009 #2 Panama Disease P Lahi 0670 (3)" by Plant pests and diseases CC BY 2.0

0.speaker: The Utopian
0.text: Your reckless disregard for life is going to ruin us all!

1.speaker: The Utopian
1.text: We have such a unique opportunity to actually make things better for everyone.

2.speaker: The Utopian
2.text: Just to keep the party going a little longer for some?

3.speaker: The Utopian
3.text: But you're squandering it...for what?

4.speaker: The Utopian
4.text: I can't stand by while you do that.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: My home is becoming too inhospitable...

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: ...disaster after disaster, always worrying about what will happen next.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: I don't want to go, but I have to. Somewhere that's safer for me and my family.

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: I know of so many others who are in a similar situation...

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: I hope one day I can go back.

image.attribution: "Kosovo Refugees" by United Nations Photo is licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 2.0

61.name: Heatwave Kills Tens of Thousands of Elderly People

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: What a tragedy. A hundred thousand people perished last week, most of them elderly.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: We have to cool things down and fast, otherwise more people will die. These disasters make people lose hope that things will get better.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: Some say that in 20 years we will see a significant shift in political ideology as the previous generations perish under the impact of climate change.

image.attribution: Parker Miller from Washington, DC, United States, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Utopian
0.text: I feel like we have a similar vision for the world.

1.speaker: The Utopian
1.text: My party will commit its seats to our shared vision and join your coalition.

2.speaker: The Utopian
2.text: "Go back again, now you have seen us, and your outward eyes have learned that in spite of all the infallible maxims of your day there is yet a time of rest in store for the world, when mastery has changed into fellowship."

3.speaker: The Utopian
3.text: Before I go, let me leave you a favorite quote from William Morris:

4.speaker: The Utopian
4.text: I look forward to working together.

image.attribution: "Amazing Frozen Bubbles by Xiaohua Hu" by University of Saskatchewan CC BY 2.0

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: We've been engaged in a lot of big projects recently, which is good but bottlenecks are inevitable.

2.speaker: The Engineer
2.text: I suggest either running fewer competing projects or we could start deep-sea mining.

image.attribution: Richard Allaway, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Earth Liberation Front
0.text: Planner! You're bias towards "technology" and "industry" is putting the world--and yourself--on a dangerous path.

1.speaker: The Earth Liberation Front
1.text: The Earth is calling for our aid and so we, the Earth Liberation Front, have returned.

2.speaker: The Earth Liberation Front
2.text: You better abandon that cozy relationship with The Accelerationist or else we'll have to take drastic action to protect the planet.

0.speaker: The Bandung Bloc
0.text: Your plans have shown nothing but contempt for my people.

1.speaker: The Bandung Bloc
1.text: I won't let that happen again.

2.speaker: The Bandung Bloc
2.text: I should have known that the promises of the revolution were just more lies to get us to play along.

3.speaker: The Bandung Bloc
3.text: Once again, we of the Global South are just fuel to burn on the altar of progress.

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: These "land hurricanes" are becoming a more common occurrence.

1.speaker: The Climatologist
1.text: If you can get the temperature anomaly under control, we should see fewer of these.

2.speaker: The Climatologist
2.text: They're basically massive high-intensity wind storms that can devastate an area.

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: Methane will run out in twenty years at current usage.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: I suggest you find another source of energy posthaste.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Some regions are really unhappy with your decisions. There are protests cropping up everywhere.

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: Your plans have only brought us more hardship! I thought you were supposed to help fix things!

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: I thought you were

0.speaker: The Farmer
0.text: We've been struck by a nasty case of wheat rust that's putting many in a shaky place with regards to food.

1.speaker: The Farmer
1.text: I know it's our policy to make sure everyone's fed, so we're working on organizing food aid to the affected areas.

2.speaker: The Malthusian
2.text: ...and try this one instead...

3.speaker: The Malthusian
3.text: You know, I think we should reconsider that policy...

image.attribution: "P. Aecia, Pycinia wheat rust 10x, shiv+matt" by stellarr CC0 1.0

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: It seems like that permafrost melting has released some ancient organism into the world.

3.speaker: The Malthusian
3.text: I think we should let it run it's course...

4.speaker: The Doctor
4.text: If we developed more advanced antibiotics, perhaps we can keep it under control.

5.speaker: The Malthusian
5.text: Highly contagious? How interesting... It's almost as if nature itself is finally doing something about overpopulation.

6.speaker: The Doctor
6.text: Yes, it's a highly contagious and dangerous bacteria. We're keeping an eye on it.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: Your plans have been a waste of our time and energy!

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: Things aren't getting better. We won't waste any more effort on ineffective action.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Wide-ranging changes are needed to put us on a long-term path towards sustainability.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: Just swipe a card into the scanner and presto! It's added to your plan.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: If you change your mind, you can swipe it down to remove it from the plan.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: Here you can use your [political_capital] political capital to wrangle support for policies to implement worldwide.

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: All our solar processes are seeing dips in output.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: Probably because of the grey skies?

2.speaker: The Engineer
2.text: I know the solar radiation management project keeps things cool, but we need energy too.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Welcome to the Gosplant planning application. You can call me Gossy.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: Got it?

5.speaker: Gossy
5.text: It's your job to guide us all safely through the next century.

6.speaker: Gossy
6.text: But you don't have complete authority to make decisions unilaterally.

7.speaker: Gossy

9.speaker: Gossy

11.speaker: Gossy

14.speaker: Gossy

16.speaker: Gossy

3.speaker: The Citizen

1.text: I guess that's a good thing? It won't last forever though.

2.speaker: The Climatologist
2.text: Now a massive volcano eruption has clouded the sky, cooling the world.

153.name: Torches and Pitchforks Outside Your Window...

0.speaker: The Authoritarian
0.text: A mob of people have raided our building! They're looking for you.

next.text: Scum! This is the only way to save the planet!
I did what I thought was best.
I didn't know what I was doing!

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: Any last words?

5.speaker: The Citizen
5.text: We are tired of living under your tyrannical plans--they've brought us nothing but misery!

0.speaker: The Malthusian
0.text: As Garrett Hardin so eloquently once said, "The freedom to breed is intolerable."

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Once you've added items to your plan, you can hit the big "Ready" button to lock it in.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: There's no rush--take your time.

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: One of the worst case scenarios has just happened...

1.speaker: The Climatologist
1.text: ...you can't sweat, so your body can't cool itself off, and so you just basically...slowly cook in the heat.

2.speaker: The Climatologist
2.text: What a horrible way to go. And to imagine that millions died in that way.

3.speaker: The Climatologist
3.text: a "wet-bulb" event, where temperature and humidity combine to be intolerable...

4.speaker: The Climatologist
4.text: Surely we could have prevented this?

image.attribution: Anderson Mancini from Sao Paulo, Brazil, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Wretched
0.text: You rich Northerners will not sacrifice half the world on your altar of greed and pseudo-ecology.

3.speaker: The Wretched
3.text: Ha, if you think there are too many people then let us help you get rid of the Malthusians!

8.speaker: The Malthusian
8.text: Planner! Either you are with us or with the Wretched. Make your choice.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: A burgeoning global population has seen intensifying urban development...

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: ...but also spillover into exurbs as some seek to escape the growing density of cities.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: Surely there are ways to counteract these impacts?

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: As you might expect, this expansion is putting more pressure onto biodiversity throughout the world.

5.speaker: Gossy
5.text: People really like living in McMansions, I guess.

image.attribution: Brett VA, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: Warmer waters means less oxygen, which is bad for most marine species. Many kinds of jellyfish, however, thrive in these conditions.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: It doesn't help that too much fishing means there are fewer predators and competitors for jellyfish.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: Even if some people care little about the oceans, they'll be annoyed when their beach holiday is ruined.

image.attribution: Eric Kilby from Somerville, MA, USA, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: We've hit an interesting milestone--the 4000th nuclear reactor was just built.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: It makes me a little bit nervous, but at least it's not as dirty as fossil fuels, eh?

image.attribution: "Salem and Hope Creek Nuclear Reactors" by peretzp is licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 2.0

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: The planning session has concluded.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: Now it's time to see what happens over the next several years.

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: Global meat consumption has gone up by almost 50% since we started.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: People may enjoy their cheeseburgers, but this comes at a huge cost to the environment, animals, and human health.

image.attribution: Pieter Brueghel the Elder, Public domain

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: The shroud from that volcanic eruption has settled, and unfortunately returned temperatures back to "normal".

0.speaker: The Alien
0.text: We have been observing your planet for some time now...

1.speaker: The Alien
1.text: ...and watched your relentless war against all other life on the planet.

4.speaker: The Alien
4.text: ...even if that means killing your pathetic species!

5.speaker: The Alien
5.text: We are obligated to defend life in all its forms!

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: These heat waves have extended all the way to the boreal forest, That's very dangerous.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: Because the boreal forest is not managed as intensely as other forests, the trees have been able to grow undisturbed, amassing large amounts of carbon in their roots and trunks. Twenty percent of the carbon held in forests in the world is in the boreal forest.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: Because the boreal forest is not managed as intensely as other forests, the trees have been able to grow undisturbed, amassing large amounts of carbon in their roots and trunks. Twenty percent of the carbon held in forests in the world is in the boreal forest.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: Frequent fire also threatens the permafrost—it can also lead to burning belowground, which melts the permafrost and can emit large amounts of carbon in a short time.

5.speaker: The Ecologist
5.text: The boreal forest is shifting from a carbon sink to a carbon source, meaning it emits more carbon than it stores.

6.speaker: The Ecologist
6.text: But most of the carbon is found in the permafrost, an underground layer of ice, rock, sand, and soil that is below freezing. The permafrost layer represents the largest carbon sink in the world.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: A copper mining operation opened near my town, even after we voted against it!

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: It's too close to us and our water supply, and people are getting stick from it!

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: I thought this kind of thing was behind us!

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: Surely there are better sites? How desperate are we for copper that we need to be put in harm's way for it?

image.attribution: National Archives at College Park, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: We've come to the end of your first planning cycle.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: Improvements will foster confidence in your planning and gain you [political_capital] political capital.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: To manage your [political_capital] political capital you'll need to balance short-term improvements with your long-term plans.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: On the flip side, setbacks and worsening conditions will lose you [political_capital] political capital.

4.speaker: Gossy
4.text: At the end of each cycle you'll be presented a report summarizing changes.

170.name: Aurochs Return to the Eurasian Plains

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: The auroch went extinct in 1627, but it has proven possible to 'back-breed' cattle and recover lost traits such as longer legs and horns.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: They will fill an important ecological niche in rewilding programs.

image.attribution: "#Tauros" by cirkel der natuur is licensed under CC BY 2.0

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: Have you been to our Havana offices?

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: We have supercomputers to make a series of global plans simulating snapshots of the future: say, five detailed blueprints of the planet five years out, ten for the coming decade, and a couple dozen for the next quarter century.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: Oh it isn't just me. Thousands of people work there from all over the world.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: Havana has had the most experience with planning, decarbonization, and organic agriculture, so I guess it made sense to put the bureau there..

4.speaker: The Ecologist
4.text: Well, the parts of the world that have joined the Half-Earth bloc all provide data, technical expertise, and proposals to the central planning bureau in Cuba.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: Heatwaves are so regular and intense nowadays...

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: It's made life more bearable, although of course not everyone can work at night.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: I hope to

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: ...most people can barely be outside during the day.

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: people sleep during the day, and do everything else at night.

5.speaker: The Citizen
5.text: My town has shifted everything to a night schedule--

6.speaker: The Citizen
6.text: I hope to see a return to some kind of normalcy one day. I miss the sun.

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: It's happening...Almost all major pollinators are on the brink of extinction.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: This will just threaten broader ecosystems even more.

2.speaker: The Farmer
2.text: We'll have to manually pollinate crops, which means yields will decline...

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: Pollinators were important to ecosystems beyond their role in agriculture too.

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: With the move away from meat consumption, livestock operations are stuck with billions of animals and nothing to do with them.

next.text: Create public sanctuaries where they can live out their final days.
We'll throw a series of feasts so they don't go to waste.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: What should we do with them?

4.speaker: The Ecologist
4.text: We can't release them into the wild because that would wreak havoc on ecosystems.

image.attribution: Photographer: Dey.sandip Additional Credit: User Atention for water spot removal., CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

177.name: From Mowing Lawns to Rewilding Meadows

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: My neighbors and I got rid of our lawns and encouraged native grasses to grow instead.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: Vole and shrew populations have rebounded, as have wildflowers like lupine (my favorite).

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: I've grown to appreciate how much we can do for our local environment, even as we try to change the world.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: Beautiful. These changes have brought a wealth of wildlife into our cities.

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: We rewilded the local golf course. I don't even miss the game as I got into birding instead.

image.attribution: Asurnipal, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: There was a major waste leakage near my town.

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: I know that myself and others in a similar situation would really like to see some sort of large-scale remediation program.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: There used to be a lot of mining and other extractive industry here, but it's long been abandoned.

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: But those damn pigs never cleaned anything up! And now we're being poisoned because of it.

image.attribution: National Archives at College Park, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Animal Liberationist
0.text: I feel like you truly have the interest of non-human life at heart.

1.speaker: The Animal Liberationist
1.text: Not many feel the same way...

2.speaker: The Animal Liberationist
2.text: My party will join your coalition.

3.speaker: The Animal Liberationist
3.text: Non-humans will finally have a voice in government!

0.speaker: The Authoritarian
0.text: I appreciate how well we've worked together...

1.speaker: The Authoritarian
1.text: We know what's best for humanity and the natural world...

2.speaker: The Authoritarian
2.text: but the other parties just get in the way.

3.speaker: The Authoritarian
3.text: If we suspend parliament we could implement our plans without any obstruction.

4.speaker: The Authoritarian
4.text: I have a proposal to take our relationship to the next level.

5.speaker: The Authoritarian
5.text: I have an idea, something we tried back in the 2010s against the anti-frackers...

6.speaker: The Authoritarian
6.text: Aren't your enemies so irritating? What can we do to restrict their reach?

0.speaker: The Earth Liberation Front
0.text: Planner--we told you to leave the earth-killing Accelerationist behind, but you wouldn't listen.

1.speaker: The Earth Liberation Front
1.text: Now we're left with no other choice but to strike at the heart of your grotesque industry!

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: The tests are in!

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: So many fewer respiratory illnesses and other complications, saving millions of lives a year.

3.speaker: The Doctor
3.text: People seem happier now. Keep up the good work!

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: My skin feels so much better, and my daughter has barely needed her inhaler in recent years.

5.speaker: The Doctor
5.text: Declining fossil fuel combustion has meant a drastic drop in air pollution.

6.speaker: The Doctor
6.text: So many fewer respiratory illnesses and other complications, saving millions of lives a year.

image.attribution: Michal Klajban, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

185.name: Millions of Climate Refugees on the Move

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: What a disaster! All those people had to leave their homes and try to make a new life in the cooler, more stable parts of the world.

1.speaker: The Authoritarian
1.text: Don't be a fool. It's their fault they didn't adapt or prove resilient in these hard times. I say we keep them out.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: We should help them, even if it will make things difficult for us here.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Large-scale projects, like mass electrification or geoengineering schemes, will help provide the foundation for a better world.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: Just like with Research cards, swipe these up to scan them and add [initiative] infrastructure points.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: Here you can turn [political_capital] political capital into [initiative] infrastructure points and use that to set build these projects.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: People aren't happy with the way things are going...

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: ...they're wrecking factories and laboratories in protest.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: This will make your plans harder to implement...

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: I’ve been living in the dorms for two years now, loved every second of it, but I’m not sure how long I’ll stay.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: Did you not see the last plan?

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: I think I’ll apply to work in Iowa when the time comes, unless these hands have gotten too old.

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: They’re letting most of Massachusetts rewild, since the soil’s not as good as out west. Right now some vegetables still make sense to grow at scale in New England, since it saves a bit on transport, at least until they finish the electric rail-lines out in the Midwest.

5.speaker: The Citizen
5.text: Once that project is done, though, this farm’s days are numbered.

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: Incredible. The greatest city our planet has ever known...

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: More like a vast networked ecology than anything designed by a human.

3.speaker: The Malthusian
3.text: Seems more like a rat's nest to me...

0.speaker: The Authoritarian
0.text: You're digging your own grave.

1.speaker: The Authoritarian
1.text: I will do whatever I can to get you to see reason.

2.speaker: The Authoritarian
2.text: Your plans mean nothing if you let people's ignorance and impulsiveness run loose.

3.speaker: The Authoritarian
3.text: It's for the best.

192.name: Ocean Plastic Weighs More than World's Fish

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: Well, this is an upsetting milestone: ocean plastic weighs more than fish.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: We still rely too heavily on fossil fuels and plastics!

image.attribution: "Thilafushi Kuni Gondu - God's dirty little secret" by Hani Amir CC BY-NC-ND 2.0

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: Biodiversity has been plummeting...

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: I don't know if it will work, but it's worth a try.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: But there may be something we can try.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: ...in case the worst should come to pass.

4.speaker: The Ecologist
4.text: I'm afraid that most of Earth's species will be lost forever.

5.speaker: The Ecologist
5.text: It would have been better if we could have stopped extinctions from happening at all.

6.speaker: The Ecologist
6.text: I propose a project to collect and store DNA samples of earth's remaining biodiversity...

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: Our reliance on hydropower as a major source of energy has meant the construction of several mega-dams across the world's waterways.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: As reservoirs fill, upstream forests are flooded, eliminating their function as carbon sinks.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: The dam constructed on the border between Paraguay and Brazil in the 1970s and 1980s, resulted in a 70 percent loss of biodiversity.

3.speaker: The Geoengineer
3.text: I for one am really impressed with our ability to shape natural environments and control water.

4.speaker: The Ecologist
4.text: I realize your intentions were good, but unfortunately you just created more problems.

5.speaker: The Engineer
5.text: We're able to produce quite a bit of power, but it has relied on the displacement of people and the damaging of ecosystems.

6.speaker: The Ecologist
6.text: And they just contributed to climate change!

7.speaker: The Ecologist
7.text: And as the drowned vegetation decomposes, decaying plants in man-made reservoirs release methane, a powerful greenhouse gas.

8.speaker: The Ecologist
8.text: Aquatic species, particularly fish, are vulnerable to the impacts of dams.

image.attribution: U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service - Northeast Region, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: There are many more birds than before because we have done so much to protect nature in recent years.

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: I like yellowhammers, one of Rosa Luxemburg's favourite birds. What's your 'spark bird'?

image.attribution: Rhododendrites, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: There's been a spike in depression and similar mental health problems as of late.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: Researchers are speculating that it has to do with the solar radiation management project...

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: living under a constant grey sky can't be good for one's mood.

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: Many people around the world are marveling at the return of local species that were once on the brink of extinction.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: I'm glad more people will be able to experience that.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: Have you ever sat and been visited by a curious animal? Or been that curious animal yourself? There's something magical about it.

image.attribution: Steve from washington, dc, usa, CC BY-SA 2.0

0.speaker: [GAME]
0.text: You step back from your planning console and let out a sigh...

1.speaker: [GAME]
1.text: Were they necessary, or did you just fumble your way through them?

2.speaker: [GAME]
2.text: You can't help but wonder how things could have gone differently.

3.speaker: [GAME]
3.text: Was this the only way?

4.speaker: [GAME]
4.text: So many unpopular and damaging decisions...

5.speaker: [GAME]
5.text: You managed to last all this time, but how has everyone else fared?

6.speaker: [GAME]
6.text: ..the weight of a century-long career shedding from your shoulders.

0.speaker: The Geoengineer
0.text: Hail cannons are an old technology—first used by Austro-Hungarian winegrowers in 1896!

201.name: Deadly Leak from CCS Storage Facility

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: CO2 is denser than air, so the deadly cloud stayed long enough at ground level to kill two thousand people and countless animals within minutes.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: We try to store CO2 as safely as we can, but some accidents are inevitable. This will be bad for morale.

203.name: Tens of Millions of Climate Migrants on the Move

0.speaker: The Malthusian
0.text: We can't let all of these people move into countries that prepared better for these crises. It's their own fault they did not create resilient societies.

1.speaker: The Malthusian
1.text: If there were fewer people, perhaps we could lower emissions. I recommend you close borders and take harsher measures.

2.speaker: The Utopian
2.text: What are you talking about? We have to help everyone we can.

image.attribution: "Kosovo Refugees" by United Nations Photo is licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 2.0

0.speaker: The Bandung Bloc
0.text: I've followed your planning for some time now, and I see you have the interests of the world at heart.

1.speaker: The Bandung Bloc
1.text: And by "world", I do mean the *whole* world, and not just the wealthy regions like some mean with that term.

2.speaker: The Bandung Bloc
2.text: My party is happy to join your coalition.

3.speaker: The Bandung Bloc
3.text: I hope that together we can undo at least some part of centuries of injustices.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: I won't make the same mistake as the last assassin.

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: Your reign is over!

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: Hurricanes are becoming much more intense on average.

1.speaker: The Climatologist
1.text: Otherwise many places will become inhospitable.

2.speaker: The Climatologist
2.text: We ought to do whatever we can to bring down the temperature to reduce their severity.

image.attribution: NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (CC BY 2.0)

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: Monsoons throughout the Indian subcontinent have been weaker and less frequent, disrupting a vital component of that region's climate.

1.speaker: The Climatologist
1.text: Residents there are understandably upset and--

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: There must be alternatives that don't require sacrificing us!

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: This is a terrible cost that we are made to bear, and we won't take it any longer!

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: I urge you to act soon. Others are talking of more aggressive ways of stopping the project.

image.attribution: Jorge Barrios, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
